n.

That's =
the British influence ... always pointing out the bleeding obvious! ;-)

>>=

>ethereal objecti=
ve

ith

care about

 shared vocabiulary at this

r that we use accepted

 to show people, so that they will accept it.

 the terminology that the process

e gonna call everything.

hallenge, when one of the

"
>
>Understood. Do you see why I don't say "unit test"? :)

Yes, but even =
managers have heard of unit testing. I can see it now ....

PROGRAMMER: "He=
y boss, I want to write some programmer tests."
MANAGER: "Not on my watch. =
Now sit down and get back to your unit testing!"

>I don't know that there =
is a definitive source that I would 
>care to use. 
>You might wish to ask =
this question on a group like 
>software-testing or 
>agile-testing.

Funny=
 you should mention that ... the good folks at comp.software.testing have a=
n FAQ that provides fairly decent definitions for most of this stuff.

http=
://www.faqs.org/faqs/software-eng/testing-faq/

Whether management will acc=
ept this as a definitive source of definitions is another question.

Simon
